The CFTC (Commodity Futures Trading Commission) has approved new rule 6.40C for the NYMEX (New York Mercantile Exchange), which relates to average price calculations by futures commission merchants. The new rule is effective as of October 3, 2000, and it allows FCMS (Futures Commission Merchants) to use their own internal, proprietary systems to generate average price ("AP") calculations when multiple prices are received on an order or series of orders.
The notice to all NYMEX and COMEX members states that the CFTC has approved new rule 6.40C, which is attached to the notice and is now in effect. The new rule allows FCMS to use their own internal, proprietary systems to generate AP calculations when multiple prices are received on an order or series of orders.
The new rule is consistent with a recent CFTC "advisory" regarding the use of internal systems for AP calculations. The advisory was issued to ensure that FCMS are using accurate and reliable methods for calculating APs, particularly in light of the increasing use of electronic trading systems and the potential for errors or discrepancies in the transmission and processing of price data.

Debra Hill, a screenwriter and producer best known for her work on the 1978 horror classic Halloween, has died in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been suffering from cancer, co-wrote the film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it made over $60 million (Â£31.3 million) worldwide - a record for independent film at the time. Hill also worked with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog.

Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way up the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before she began collaborating with Carpenter. She was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in film, taking on jobs in the 1970s that were more commonly taken by men.

However, the unit was sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm Rosneft, but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos' lawyers now say that the auction violated US bankruptcy law.
